advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE LOGO (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Apple Logo was a very successful implementation of Logo. It contained some advanced features such as property list and packages, as well as extremely good documentation.<br><br> At the time, Apple thought the Logo language would encourage schools to invest heavily in personal computers for all the class levels.<br> Sadly, Logo never became the revolutionary language that they had hoped for and very few schools taught it to their pupils (except in France).</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://club.pep.ne.jp/~p.katsu/pasocata/index.html">P.KATSU</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (JULY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil has all talents"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert from Byte magazine (january 1977) said : <br><br> ...It gets its speed and power from a selected version of the new Z80 microprocessor that can operate at a 4 Mhz. clock rate (The Z-1 also lets you switch to 2 Mhz. to be compatible with older systems)...<br> ...The Z-1 offers you all kinds of peripherals and softwares. It uses the standard ''S100'' bus supported by over a dozen manufacturers. And all Cromemco peripherals (PROM memory and programmer, Ram memory, analog I/O, color TV interface, etc) just plug into the Z1's sockets...<br> ... The Z-1 comes completely assembled ans tested. It's a quality, commercial grade microcomputer. It is not available as a kit.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>These in an advert from 84, for 3 models of Hectors (Hector 16k, Hector 2HR+ 48k & Hector HRX 64k).</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. 1983 #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Hard disk version<br><br> "<font color="#666666">No matter how you look at it, KAYPRO is the best value you will see anawhere...</font>"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This ad is unique in that it features professional actors and IMSAI employees. <p class="petitgris">Thomas Fischer</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>''For less than 2000 francs, offer yourself the future'' ...yes</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SEMI-TECH BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, OCT. 1981</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, October 1981.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of '<a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a>'</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RADIOLA ADVERT. 1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZELAND AD. (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> The renaissance machine is a "one-of-a-kind" system for the "one-of-a-kind" person who demands and will not settle for anything less than, the best.</font><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zeland</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPARISON CHART</strong></font><br><blockquote>This document compares the different Panasonic systems of the serie<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href=§http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage§>Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ISAAC ASIMOV #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This November 1982 advert introduces the new CoCo 1 price : $299 instead of $399.<br><br> Even if the advert said:<br><font color="#666666">"Hurry - this fantastic offer ends december 31, 1982" </font><br>the price never came back to $399.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> IIE VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>Promotional picture. Notice the dual floppy drive module on top of the case, inspired by the Franklin <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/museum/computer.asp?st=1&c=646" target="_blank">ACE 1200</a><p class="petitgris">Roberto Isiri</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Gazelle was a huge computer compared to the personal computer sizes of the time, so large that it has casters on the cabinet for moving it!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This french advert dated may 1980, shows the first model sold in France. It was called Victor Lambda and the company name was Lambda Systemes. This model was nothing more than an Interact computer, sold with an english documentation and a NTSC television !</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BAKED APPLE</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, October 1981<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of '<a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a>'</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT FS II, APR. 1986</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: 10 games : target 1, target 2, basket 1, basket 2, gridball, squash 1, squash 2, football, tennis, ice hockey
computer.coprocessor: power on/off, speed slow/fast, player 1 bat size (large/small), player 2 bat size (large/small), service auto/manual
computer.description:
This pong is one of the many Binatone systems. As its name indicates, it offers 10 games : 8 pong games (basket 1, basket 2, gridball, squash 1, squash 2, football, tennis, ice hockey) and 2 shooting games (target 1, target 2). It is the most complete of the Binatone TV Master serie (black & white pongs).
In order to understand how this system fits into the Binatone pong range, here is simplified list of the systems :
TV Master MK IV TV Master 4 plus 2 TV Master MK 6 TV Master MK 8 TV Master MK 10
Colour TV Game Colour TV Game 4 plus 2 Colour TV Game MK 6 Colour TV Game MK 10
The TV master serie are black & white pongs (first generation). The TV Master MK 10 system is the same as the Colour TV Game MK 10 except that games are in black & white, while the Colour TV game displays colour games.
Game selection is made through 10 individual push buttons. The two detachable controllers are composed of an analog joystick and a fire button. The shape of the plastic case is different from the Binatone Colour TV Game MK 10, which is to be noted as the Colour TV game systems usually use the same one as their TV Master counterparts.
Interestingly enough, both shooting games are not played with a light gun but directly with the analog joysticks.
This system seems to be powered by a General Instruments AY-3-8610 chipset, which equiped a lot of other pong systems (anyone can confirm ?).
computer.keyboard: Two detachable paddles with analog joystick and fire button
computer.language: 10 games : target 1, target 2, basket 1, basket 2, gridball, squash 1, squash 2, football, tennis, ice hockey
computer.name: TV Master MK 10 (model n? 01 / 4834)
computer.ports: RF TV video output, 2 x controller plugs
computer.sound: Minimalist beeps via the TV speakers or built-in speakers ?
